Abstract of Doctoral Thesis presented to Escola de Qu√≠mica/UFRJ as part of the requirements to obtain the degree of Doctor in Science (D.Sc.) in Chemical and Biochemical Processes Engineering .

EVALUATION OF THE CORROSION INHIBITORY POTENTIAL OF PEUMUS BOLDUS EXTRACT S AND SCHIFF BASES FOR APPLICATION IN OIL WELL ACIDI ZING FLUIDS LUANA BARROS FURTADO Advisors : Maria Jos√© de O liveira Cavalcanti Guimar√£es, D Sc.
Jos√© Ant √¥nio da Cunha Ponciano Gomes, D Sc.

Peter Rudolf Seidl, PhD The acidi zing operation aims to increase the productivity of the wells through the use of acid solutions. Such solutions can compromise the integrity of metallic materials, which are susceptible to several corrosion mechanisms, requiring the use of corrosion inhibitors. Due to environmental problems, e co-friendly corrosion inhibitors have been investigated . These inhibitors reduce or eliminate the use of toxic solvents, as well as minimize the generation of products and by -products harmful to health or the environment, maintaining high efficiency in high temperatures. In this sense, the objective of this work was to develop corro sion inhibit ory formulations containing active compounds from Boldo -do-Chile extract and Schiff bases. Boldo -do-Chile is a corrosion inhibitor due to the presence of phenolic compounds and the boldine molecule, which has nitrogen heteroatom . Schiff bases a re synthetic compounds that have a nitrogen heteroatom in the ‚ÄìC = N bond , which contributes to its inhibitory character associated with the electronic density of the aromatic rings. Thus, boldo -do-Chile was investigated as a corrosion inhibitor for carbon steel API P110 in 2 M HCl and 15%. Full two -level factorial design (23) was used to optimize the extraction time, temperature and the leaf / ethanol ratio. The extracts were characterized for phenolic content, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and h ydrogen nuclear magnetic resonance, confirming the presence of aromatic compounds and aliphatic structures. The concentration of the extract in HCl 2 M was evaluated at 30 and 40¬∞C, with an efficiency of 87%. Binary formulations were developed to partially reduce the use of conventional inhibitors, resulting in two potential formulations for oil well acidizing at 60¬∞C. Regarding the Schiff bases, three compounds (SB1, SB2 and SB3) were synthesized from a natural aldehyde (vanillin) and aromatic amines, being evaluated as corrosion inhibitors for API P110 carbon steel in 2 M HCl and 15%. The compounds were chara cterized by infrared spectroscopy and hydrogen nuclear magnetic resonance, confirming the synthesis of the Schiff bases. Performance evaluation as an inhibitor was performed at 40 -80¬∞C at concentrations of 0.4 and 1.0% w t./v. The highest efficiency (98.72% ) was obtained in 2 M HCl at 60¬∞C. Binary and ternary formulations were developed in order to reduce corrosion rates in HCl 15%. The potassium iodide blends resulted in a maximum efficiency of 97.78% in 15% HCl at 60¬∞C. Electrochemical tests for both Boldo -do-Chile formulations and Schiff bases indicated that the formulations are of mixed type. Laser scanning confocal microscopy showed more regular metal surface morphology in the presence of the formulations, in addition to elucidating light localized corro sion. Finally, formulation F (2.0% w t./v) was developed, combining the active components (extract of boldo -do-Chile and SB3), intensifying coadjuvants and a compatibilizer. Such formulation made it possible to achieve corrosion rates below 5 mm/y at x

80¬∞C. The formulation F was also evaluated in the protection of 17%Cr and S13 steels, exhibiting a better performance for the latter. Keywords: Corrosion inhibitor, well acidification, organic formulations.
